newsitem.title: UK: Wet Brent trades wide apart, clockings weaken tone.
newsitem.headline: Wet Brent trades wide apart, clockings weaken tone.

text.p: Two wet Brent trades at sharply variant levels briefly puzzled the North Sea crude market on Friday afternoon, but when the dust settled the sentiment was slightly weaker, traders said.
A Feb 11-13 cargo which fetched Mar Brent +42 cents on Thursday was resold at Mar Brent +44 cents on Friday. But a Feb 14-16 loader later traded at Mar Brent +33 cents, traders said.
"I wouldn't put the market over 40," a trader said. "The 44 deal looks a bit contrived to me."
Some traders said the buyer of the higher priced Brent was sitting on a big Feb paper position.
Compounding the slightly bearish sentiment among most in the market was the clocking of four of the five Brent dates turning wet on Friday.
One cargo loading Feb 17-19 was kept by U.S. trader JP Morgan which was heard back on offer at Mar Brent +40 cents late in the day.
JP Morgan was clocked with another cargo along with BP and Mobil. Morgan Stanley and BP were in dispute over the fifth.
Other North Sea crudes held firm, a Gullfaks A was traded at Dated Brent +30 cents, and a Troll was heard traded at Dated +53 cents.
Brent paper supported the weaker end of Friday's physical trades. CFDs for next week were pegged at Mar Brent +32/36 late in the day, with the following week at Mar Brent +14/17.
Feb/Mar Brent was thinly talked but valued around +64, while Mar/Apr was talked at +49/53, having traded at +49 and +50 cts.
March Brent outright was trading 26 cents weaker on the IPE screen at $22.92 a barrel at 1836 GMT.

In the Mediterranean, Russian Urals held steady at around Dated Brent -65/70. Local refiners complained about poor margins, but traders said that scarce supplies were supporting levels. --Rosalind Russell, London Newsroom +44 171 542 5387
